title: Cellulitis vs. Necrotizing Infection
diagnosis_topic: Differentiating simple cellulitis from early necrotizing fasciitis
setup_script: A 50-year-old woman presents with a rapidly enlarging red, warm area on her right thigh. She reports severe pain out of proportion to the redness and has a low-grade fever.

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 125/80 mmHg, HR 102 bpm, RR 20/min, Temp 38 C.
Erythematous plaque extending 10 cm with indistinct borders; no bullae or crepitus yet; exquisitely tender to palpation.
WBC 16 K/uL, CRP elevated, sodium low at 131 mEq/L (LRINEC score high).

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident initiates empiric IV antibiotics
dynamic_flow.reply: Started on vancomycin plus piperacillin-tazobactam while awaiting further assessment.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident marks the edges of erythema and monitors progression
dynamic_flow.reply: Erythema expands 2 cm over 1 hour suggesting rapid progression.
CT scan shows thickened fascia and small foci of gas in soft tissues.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident calls for emergent surgical evaluation
dynamic_flow.reply: Exploration reveals gray necrotic fascia confirming necrotizing fasciitis.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays consultation thinking it is simple cellulitis
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient deteriorates quickly with septic shock.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident educates about differentiating features
dynamic_flow.reply: Disproportionate pain, bullae, systemic toxicity and rapid spread suggest necrotizing process.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident states that cellulitis alone often responds to oral antibiotics
dynamic_flow.reply: For cellulitis without systemic features, oral beta-lactams suffice.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident discusses the LRINEC score
dynamic_flow.reply: Helps risk-stratify patients but should not delay surgical exploration when suspicion is high.
ICU management, repeat debridements and broad-spectrum antibiotics continued.

critical_decision_points: High index of suspicion for necrotizing infection when pain is disproportionate
Use of lab markers and imaging to support diagnosis without delaying surgery
Early initiation of broad-spectrum antibiotics and surgical consultation
Understanding limitations of the LRINEC score and the need for clinical judgement
Postoperative management including repeat exploration and intensive care
